docs.lead_paragraph: With the start of open-enrollment season, it's time to become your own miniature human resources department. Here are the first steps toward making the best choices for the year ahead. OPEN THOSE ENVELOPES Doing nothing is no longer an option. Many companies insist you fill out open-enrollment forms even if you intend to stay with the same benefits package.

headline.main: When Open-Enrollment Envelopes Arrive, Open Them

docs.snippet: This year, more than ever before, it is important to read the fine print in notices offering the opportunity to switch health insurers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Roland Burris, Democrat of Illinois, doesn't get a whole lot of attention in the Capitol. He arrived in the Senate under a cloud, appointed by the soon-to-be impeached Gov. Rod Blagojevich, and has remained mostly obscured from view. Mr. Blagojevich was removed from office. Mr. Burris said he would not run in 2010 to keep his seat. And he seemed to fade even further.

headline.main: In Quest for 60 Senate Votes, No Democrat Left Behind

docs.abstract: In the Senate health care debate, even the vote of Blagojevich's lame-duck appointee could matter.

docs.lead_paragraph: From around the world and at home, reaction to the news that President Obama had won the Nobel Peace prize -- less than nine months into his presidency -- was mixed with a bit of amusement and confusion.

docs.lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

headline.main: Should Medicare Benefits Start Later in Life?

docs.lead_paragraph: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is questioning the positive conclusions given to Citigroup's management team in a government-mandated review in the aftermath of the financial crisis, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the situation.
